Posts.Content: sailorbev wrote: I am considering IORT but am having trouble finding out if it is covered by my insurance. The surgeon I saw yesterday does not do it and would have to refer me 2 hours away for IORT. I don't want to bother with the consultation if it isn't covered by insurance and my insurance company can't tell me without the billing code. I feel like I am in a Catch-22. Has anyone else has trouble with insurance coverage Dx 4/20/2015, IDC, Right, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 1, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- (IHC) Surgery 5/29/2015 Lumpectomy: Right; Lymph node removal: Sentinel Radiation Therapy 7/8/2015 Whole-breast: Breast Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: IORT and Insurance Coverage sailorbev savgigi

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2015 07:56AM sailorbev wrote: Thank you for your responses. savgigi and gypsyjo, are you happy with your choice of IORT?
Posts.Title: IORT and Insurance Coverage sailorbev savgigi

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2015 09:48AM sailorbev wrote: I just came across an article on this site that says some older women may not need radiation after lumpectomy. "This suggests that some women older than 60 diagnosed with luminal A disease -- hormone-receptor-positive, HER2-negative breast cancer with low levels of Ki-67 -- who are taking hormonal therapy after surgery may be able to skip radiation therapy. While the results of this study are very encouraging, more research is needed before doctors can say for certain if some older women diagnosed with luminal A breast cancer can avoid radiation therapy." Even though the study says more research is needed I think I will discuss this with my surgeon. I fit the profile in the study, I am 61, stage 1, grade 1, ER positive 100%, PR positive 10%, HER2 negative, Ki-67 <10%. Has anyone else done this or considered it
Posts.Title: Stage 1 clear nodes no radiation or chemo? Taramay hummingbirdlover
